refnamediv.refpurpose: an extended version of &pdfTeX; using &Lua; as an embedded scripting language

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: Run the &luaTeX; typesetter on file, usually creating file.pdf. Any remaining commands are processed as &luaTeX; input, after file is read.
Alternatively, if the first non-option argument begins with a &, the next word is taken as the format to read, overriding all else. Any remaining arguments are processed as above.
If no arguments or options are specified, prompt for input.

&luaTeX; is an extended version of &pdfTeX; with Unicode and OpenType font support, embeded &Lua; scripting language, the &eTeX; and Ω extensions, as well as integrated &MetaPost; engine, that can create &PDF; files as well as &DVI; files.
You can read the &luaTeX; manual using the &MiKTeXHelpUtility; (run &mthelp; luatex).
All &luaTeX; text input and output is considered to be Unicode text.
In &DVI; mode, &luaTeX; can be used as a complete replacement for the &TeX; engine.

In &PDF; mode, &luaTeX; can natively handle the &PDF;, &JPG;, &JBIG2;, and &PNG; graphics formats. &luaTeX; cannot include &PostScript; or Encapsulated &PostScript; (&EPS;) graphics files; first convert them to &PDF; using &miktexepstopdf; (consult the miktex-epstopdf1 manual page).

refsect1.title: Options
refsect1.para: When the &luaTeX; executable starts, it looks for the --lua commandline option. If there is no --lua option, the commandline is interpreted in a similar fashion as in traditional &pdfTeX;. But if the option is present, &luaTeX; will enter an alternative mode of commandline parsing in comparison to the standard &MiKTeX; programs. The presence of --lua makes most of other options unreliable, because the &Lua; initialization file can disable path searching and/or hook functions into various callbacks.

listitem.para:
Switch on draft mode.
--draftmode
luaTeX; doesn't write a &PDF; and doesn't read any included images, thus speeding up execution.

Load and execute a
--lua=file
&Lua; initialization script.

Use string
--output-comment=string
for &DVI; file comment instead of date.

Use format
--output-format=format
for job output (one of: dvi, pdf).
